Multipoint LDP (mLDP) In-Band Signaling with Wildcards
Abstract
contents.ja: 抽象

contents.text: There are scenarios in which an IP multicast tree traverses an MPLS domain. In these scenarios, it can be desirable to convert the IP multicast tree "seamlessly" into an MPLS Multipoint Label Switched Path (MP-LSP) when it enters the MPLS domain, and then to convert it back to an IP multicast tree when it exits the MPLS domain. Previous documents specify procedures that allow certain kinds of IP multicast trees (either Source-Specific Multicast trees or Bidirectional Multicast trees) to be attached to an MPLS Multipoint Label Switched Path (MP-LSP). However, the previous documents do not specify procedures for attaching IP Any-Source Multicast trees to MP-LSPs, nor do they specify procedures for aggregating multiple IP multicast trees onto a single MP-LSP. This document specifies the procedures to support these functions. It does so by defining "wildcard" encodings that make it possible to specify, when setting up an MP-LSP, that a set of IP multicast trees, or a shared IP multicast tree, should be attached to that MP-LSP. Support for non-bidirectional IP Any-Source Multicast trees is subject to certain applicability restrictions that are discussed in this document. This document updates RFCs 6826 and 7246.

contents.ja: 1.はじめに

contents.text: [RFC6826] and [RFC7246] specify procedures for mLDP (Multipoint LDP) that allow an IP multicast tree (either a Source-Specific Multicast tree or a Bidirectional Multicast tree) to be attached "seamlessly" to an MPLS Multipoint Label Switched Path (MP-LSP). This can be useful, for example, when there is multicast data that originates in a domain that supports IP multicast, which then has to be forwarded across a domain that supports MPLS multicast and then has to forwarded across another domain that supports IP multicast. By attaching an IP multicast tree to an MP-LSP, data that is traveling along the IP multicast tree can be moved seamlessly to the MP-LSP when it enters the MPLS multicast domain. The data then travels along the MP-LSP through the MPLS domain. When the data reaches the boundary of the MPLS domain, it can be moved seamlessly to an IP multicast tree. This ability to attach IP multicast trees to MPLS MP-LSPs can be useful in either VPN context or global context.

contents.text: In mLDP, every MP-LSP is identified by the combination of a "root node" (or "Ingress Label Switching Router (LSR)") and an "Opaque Value" that, in the context of the root node, uniquely identifies the MP-LSP. These are encoded into an mLDP "Forwarding Equivalence Class (FEC) Element". To set up an MP-LSP, the Egress LSRs originate mLDP control messages containing the FEC element. A given FEC Element value identifies a single MP-LSP and is passed upstream from the Egress LSRs, through the intermediate LSRs, to the Ingress LSR.

contents.text: In IP multicast, a multicast tree is identified by the combination of an IP source address ("S") and an IP group address ("G"), usually written as "(S,G)". A tree carrying traffic of multiple sources is identified by its group address, and the identifier is written as "(*,G)".
contents.ja: IPマルチキャストでは、マルチキャストツリーはIPソースアドレス（「S」）およびIPグループアドレス（「G」）の組み合わせによって識別され、通常、「（S、G）」と記します。複数のソースのトラフィックを運ぶ木は、そのグループアドレスによって識別され、識別子は「（*、G）」のように記述されています。

contents.text: When an MP-LSP is being set up, the procedures of [RFC6826] and [RFC7246], known as "mLDP in-band signaling", allow the Egress LSRs of the MP-LSP to encode the identifier of an IP multicast tree in the "Opaque Value" field of the mLDP FEC Element that identifies the MP-LSP. Only the Egress and Ingress LSRs are aware that the mLDP FEC Elements contain encodings of the IP multicast tree identifier; intermediate nodes along the MP-LSP do not take any account of the internal structure of the FEC Element's Opaque Value, and the internal structure of the Opaque Value does not affect the operation of mLDP. By using mLDP in-band signaling, the Egress LSRs of an MP-LSP inform the Ingress LSR that they expect traffic of the identified IP multicast tree (and only that traffic) to be carried on the MP-LSP. That is, mLDP in-band signaling not only sets up the MP-LSP, it also binds a given IP multicast tree to the MP-LSP.

The purpose of mLDP in-band signaling is to eliminate the need for these other protocols.

contents.text: When following the procedures of [RFC6826] and [RFC7246] for non-bidirectional trees, the Opaque Value has an IP source address (S) and an IP group address (G) encoded into it, thus enabling it to identify a particular IP multicast (S,G) tree. Only a single IP source-specific multicast tree (i.e., a single "(S,G)") can be identified in a given FEC element. As a result, a given MP-LSP can carry data from only a single IP source-specific multicast tree (i.e., a single "(S,G) tree"). However, there are scenarios in which it would be desirable to aggregate a number of (S,G) trees on a single MP-LSP. Aggregation allows a given number of IP multicast trees to use a smaller number of MP-LSPs, thus saving state in the network.

contents.text: 4.1. PIM Shared Tree Forwarding
contents.ja: 4.1。 PIM共有ツリーフォワーディング

contents.text: PIM [RFC4601] has the concept of a "shared tree", identified as (*,G). This concept is only applicable when G is an IP multicast group address that is not in the SSM address range (i.e., is an ASM group address). Every ASM group is associated with a Rendezvous Point (RP), and the (*,G) tree is built towards the RP (i.e., its root is the RP). The RP for group G is responsible for forwarding packets down the (*,G) tree. The packets forwarded down the (*,G) tree may be from any multicast source, as long as they have an IP destination address of G.
contents.ja: PIM [RFC4601]は（*、G）として識別 "共有ツリー" の概念を有しています。この概念は、Gは、SSMアドレス範囲内にないIPマルチキャストグループアドレスである場合にのみ適用可能である（すなわち、ASMグループアドレスです）。すべてのASM基はランデブーポイント（RP）に関連付けられ、（*、G）ツリーはRPに向かって構築されている（すなわち、そのルートがRPです）。グループGのためのRPは（*、G）ツリーの下パケットを転送する責任があります。 （*、G）ツリーをダウン転送されたパケットであれば、それらがGのIP宛先アドレスを有するように、任意のマルチキャストソースからのものであってもよいです

contents.text: The RP learns about all the multicast sources for a given group and then joins a source-specific tree for each such source. That is, when the RP for G learns that S has multicast data to send to G, the RP joins the (S,G) tree. When the RP receives multicast data from S that is destined to G, the RP forwards the data down the (*,G) tree. There are several different ways that the RP may learn about the sources for a given group. The RP may learn of sources via PIM Register messages [RFC4601], via Multicast Source Discovery Protocol (MSDP) [RFC3618], or by observing packets from a source that is directly connected to the RP.
contents.ja: RPは、与えられたグループのすべてのマルチキャスト送信元について学習した後、このような各ソースのソース固有のツリーに参加します。それはGのためのRPはSがGに送信するマルチキャストデータを持っていることを知るとき、RPは（S、G）木に参加する、です。 RPは、Gを宛先としているSからマルチキャストデータを受信すると、RPは（*、G）ツリー下りデータを転送します。 RPは、特定のグループのための情報源について学ぶことがいくつかの異なる方法があります。 RPは、PIM登録メッセージ[RFC4601]を介して、マルチキャストソース発見プロトコル（MSDP）[RFC3618]を介して、または直接RPに接続されたソースからのパケットを観察することによって、ソースを知ることができます。

contents.text: In PIM, a PIM router that has receivers for a particular ASM multicast group G (known as a "last hop" router for G) will first join the (*,G) tree. As it receives multicast traffic on the (*,G) tree, it learns (by examining the IP headers of the multicast data packets) the sources that are transmitting to G. Typically, when a last hop router for group G learns that source S is transmitting to G, the last hop router joins the (S,G) tree and "prunes" S off the (*,G) tree. This allows each last hop router to receive the multicast data along the shortest path from the source to the last hop router. (Full details of this behavior can be found in [RFC4601].)
contents.ja: PIM、（G用の「最後のホップ」ルーターとして知られている）特定のASMマルチキャストグループGのための受信機を有し、PIMルータの最初の（*、G）ツリーに参加します。それは上のマルチキャストトラフィックを受信するように（*、G）ツリーは、それがグループGの最後のホップルータは、そのソースSを学習する場合、通常Gに送信しているソース、（マルチキャストデータパケットのIPヘッダを調べることによって）学習Gに送信され、最後のホップルータは、（*、G）木オフ（S、G）ツリーと「プルーン」Sに参加します。これは、各最終ホップルータが最後のホップルータへのソースからの最短経路に沿ってマルチキャストデータを受信することを可能にします。 （この現象の完全な詳細は、[RFC4601]に見出すことができます。）

contents.text: In some cases, however, a last hop router for group G may decide not to join the source trees, but rather to keep receiving all the traffic for G from the (*,G) tree. In this case, we say that the last hop router has "threshold infinity" for group G. This is optional behavior documented in [RFC4601]. "Threshold infinity" is often used in deployments where the RP is between the multicast sources and the multicast receivers for group G, i.e., in deployments where it is known that the shortest path from any source to any receiver of the group goes through the RP. In these deployments, there is no advantage for a last hop router to join a source tree since the data is already traveling along the shortest path. The only effect of executing the complicated procedures for joining a source tree and pruning the source off the shared tree would be to increase the amount of multicast routing state that has to be maintained in the network.
contents.ja: しかし、場合によっては、グループGの最後のホップルータは、ソースツリーに参加しないことを決定してもよいのではなく、（*、G）木からGのすべてのトラフィックを受信し続けるために。この場合、我々は最後のホップルータは、グループGのための「しきい値無限大」を持っていること。これは、[RFC4601]で文書化オプションの動作であると言います。 「しきい値の無限」は、しばしば、グループの任意の受信機への任意のソースからの最短経路はRPを通過することが知られている展開で、RPは、グループGのマルチキャストソースとマルチキャスト受信機との間で展開、すなわちで使用され。これらの展開では、データが既に最短経路に沿って走行しているので、ソースツリーに参加する最後のホップルータの利点はありません。ソースツリーに参加し、共有ツリーオフソースを剪定するための複雑な手順を実行する唯一の効果は、ネットワーク内で維持されなければならないマルチキャストルーティング状態の量を増加させるであろう。

contents.text: To efficiently use mLDP in-band signaling in this scenario, it is necessary for the Egress LSRs to construct an Opaque Value TLV that identifies a (*,G) tree. This is done by using the wildcard in the IP source address subfield and setting the IP group address subfield to G.

contents.text: 4.2. IGMP/MLD Proxying
contents.ja: 4.2。 IGMP / MLDプロキシ

contents.text: There are scenarios where the multicast senders and receivers are directly connected to an MPLS routing domain, and where it is desired to use mLDP rather than PIM to set up "trees" through that domain.
contents.ja: そこマルチキャスト送信者と受信者が直接MPLSルーティングドメインに接続されているシナリオがあり、そのドメインを介して「木」を設定するMLDPなくPIMを使用することが所望されます。

contents.text: In these scenarios, we can apply "IGMP/MLD proxying" and eliminate the use of PIM. The senders and receivers consider the MPLS domain to be single hop between each other. [RFC4605] documents procedures where a multicast routing protocol is not necessary to build a "simple tree". Within the MPLS domain, mLDP will be used to build an MP-LSP, but this is hidden from the senders and receivers. The procedures defined in [RFC4605] are applicable since the senders and receivers are considered to be one hop away from each other.
contents.ja: これらのシナリオでは、「IGMP / MLDプロキシを」適用し、PIMの使用を排除することができます。送信側と受信側は、MPLSドメインが互いの間の単一のホップであると考えています。 [RFC4605]は、マルチキャストルーティングプロトコルは、「単純なツリー」を構築する必要がなく、手順を文書化します。 MPLSドメイン内では、MLDPはMP-LSPを構築するために使用されますが、これは送信者と受信者から隠されています。 [RFC4605]で定義された手順は、送信者ので適用可能であり、受信機は1つのホップ互いからであると考えられます。

contents.text: For mLDP to build the necessary MP-LSP, it needs to know the root of the tree. Following the procedures as defined in [RFC4605], we depend on manual configuration of the mLDP root for the ASM multicast group. Since the MP-LSP for a given ASM multicast group will carry traffic from all the sources for that group, the Opaque Value TLV used to construct the MP-LSP will contain a wildcard in the IP source address subfield.
contents.ja: MLDPが必要なMP-LSPを構築するためには、ツリーのルートを知っている必要があります。 [RFC4605]で定義されている手順に従って、我々は、ASMマルチキャストグループのMLDPルートの手動設定に依存します。所与ASMマルチキャストグループ用のMP-LSPは、そのグループのすべてのソースからのトラフィックを伝送するので、不透明値TLVは、IPソースアドレスサブフィールドにワイルドカードを含むことになるMP-LSPを構築するために使用されます。

contents.text: 4.3. Selective Source Mapping
contents.ja: 4.3。選択ソースマッピング

contents.text: In many IPTV deployments, the content servers are gathered into a small number of sites. Popular channels are often statically configured and forwarded over a core MPLS network to the Egress routers. Since these channels are statically defined, they MAY also be forwarded over a multipoint LSP with wildcard encoding. The sort of wildcard encoding that needs to be used (source and/or group) depends on the source/group allocation policy of the IPTV provider. Other options are to use MSDP [RFC3618] or BGP "Auto-Discovery" procedures [RFC6513] for source discovery by the Ingress LSR. Based on the received wildcard, the Ingress LSR can select from the set of IP multicast streams for which it has state.

contents.text: [RFC6826] and [RFC7246] describe procedures by which an Egress LSR may determine the MP-LSP root node address corresponding to a given (S,G) IP multicast stream. contents.text: 8. Anycast RP
contents.ja: 8.エニーキャストRP

contents.text: In the scenarios where mLDP in-band signaling is used, it is unlikely that the RP-to-group mappings are being dynamically distributed over the MPLS core. It is more likely that the RP address is statically configured at each multicast site. In these scenarios, it is advisable to configure an Anycast RP address at each site in order to provide redundancy. See [RFC3446] for more details.
